subject: Re: Message from Samer Takrit
original_content:
Samer,

I am glad this problem has been taken care of.
Hope everything is going well for you.
I shall get in touch with you before coming to New York City.

Happy Holidays an the best of luck.

Vince





Shirley Crenshaw
12/11/2000 08:13 AM
To: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:

Vince:

Samer asked me to forward this to you (he was using the wrong email address).

I will forward him the correct address.

Shirley

Thank you for forwarding Samer’s message—I appreciate the heads-up. I’ve noted the details regarding the issue and will reach out to Samer directly once I’ve corrected his email address (thanks for the fix—my apologies for the oversight).

Wishing Samer all the best with the resolution, and I’ll connect with him before my trip to NYC next week. Let me know if there’s anything else you’d like me to address in the meantime.

Best regards,
**Vince Kaminski**

subject: Re: Stanford OR - Summer Intern
original_content:
Ravi,

I shall leave the decision to Stinson and you.

Vince




Ravi Thuraisingham@ENRON COMMUNICATIONS on 02/23/2000 11:39:01 AM
To: Stinson Gibner/HOU/ECT@ECT, Vince Kaminski
cc:  
Subject: Stanford OR - Summer Interns

Hi this is one of the junior PhD students that we've visited in Stanford.  
Are we interested in bringing him to Enron Research and or EBS research. 
I'll have to think about his role in EBS.

Ravi.
----- Forwarded by Ravi Thuraisingham/Enron Communications on 02/23/00 11:32 
AM -----

	shikhar@stanford.edu
	02/20/00 07:24 PM
		 
		 To: Ravi.Thuraisingham.Enron_Communications@enron.com
		 cc: Ravi.Thuraisingham@enron.com, (bcc: Ravi Thuraisingham/Enron 
Communications)
		 Subject: Stanford OR - Summer Interns



Hi Ravi:

Please find attached my resume for the summer internship program. I
apologize for the delay. We actually lost your contact info. Please let me
know if you will need any additional information and/or a cover letter
besides the resume and I can send it right away.

Thanks

Regards,
Shikhar

Vince delegates Stanford PhD intern decision to Ravi and Stinson. Ravi inquires about hiring a Stanford intern for Enron/EBS. Shikhar emails his resume for a summer internship, requesting follow-up. **Addressed to:** Ravi, Stinson, Vince.

**Dear Ravi and Stinson,**

I wanted to follow up on the delegation of the Stanford PhD internship decision and provide a quick update on the next steps.

As discussed, Ravi, you’re leading the evaluation for the Enron/EBS internship. Shikhar Ghosh has submitted his resume for consideration—please let me know if you’d like to schedule an interview or need further details.

Vince, if there’s anything else you’d like me to coordinate regarding this process, just let me know.

Looking forward to your thoughts.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
vince.kaminski@enron.co

---

subject: Re: Pricing Power Derivative
original_content:
Marcus,

I have this paper buried at home among other electricity related papers.
I shall look for it this weekend.

Vince





Marcus Jagdeo@ENRON
03/30/2001 09:05 AM
To: Vince J Kaminski/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Pricing Power Derivatives

Hi Vince,

It was a pleasure meeting you during your visit to London.  I hope that all 
is well with you.  Steve, Sharad, Slava and myself sat down today with my PhD 
supervisor to more or less concrete what my thesis will be based on.  To 
start off, I will be working on a price process for power that is tied to the 
stack model.  I imagine that later on we will be pricing power derivatives 
off of this or modifications of it.  Steve has recommended a good paper  - 
"Pricing Power Derivatives" by Geman and Eydeland.  I will be implementing 
their model as that would be a very good departure for me and might also 
prove to be useful to Enron.  The only unfortunate thing is that we are 
unable to locate the paper.  With this in mind, I thought that you might have 
a copy readily available.  Steve and I will continue to look but any 
assistance would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks in advance and take care.

Best regards,

Marcus
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Marcus (Enron) emails Vince requesting the *"Pricing Power Derivatives"* paper by Geman & Eydeland—needed for his PhD thesis on power derivatives modeling. Vince replies he’ll fetch it from home. **To:** Vince Kaminski (ECT).
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Request for *"Pricing Power Derivatives"* Paper by Geman & Eydeland

**Dear Vince,**

I hope this email finds you well. I’m reaching out regarding the *"Pricing Power Derivatives"* paper by Geman and Eydeland—it would be a huge help for my PhD thesis on power derivatives modeling. Could you locate a copy and send it over when convenient? I’d greatly appreciate it.

Let me know if you run into any issues—I’m happy to assist if needed.

Best regards,
**Marcus**

---
*P.S. No rush, but I’d like to get started on this as soon as possible.* *(Optional, if urgency is implied.)*
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Re: Geman & Eydeland Paper

Hi Marcus,

I’ve got the Geman and Eydeland paper on power derivatives—it’s buried in my files among some other electricity-related materials. I’ll send it over to you by end of day.

Let me know if you run into any other snags with your thesis work.

Best,
Vince

subject: (No Subject)
original_content:
Spotlight Report
  Exchange products seeing slow trading
  GAVIN SOUTER

  03/20/2000
  Business Insurance
  Page 3
  Copyright (C) 2000 Crain Communications, Inc. All rights
  reserved.

  Exchange-based insurance products developed in recent years have
  been somewhat slow to get off the ground.

  Although several exchanges have offered derivative contracts since
  the mid-1990s to cover insurance risks, none so far has posted a
  significant volume of trades.

  Few insurers, reinsurers or policyholders have been drawn away
  from the traditional insurance markets, where capacity remains
  abundant and relatively cheap.

  As long as those traditional markets manage to weather major
  natural catastrophes, the allure of the exchange-based products will
  remain limited, observers say.

  Also stifling the growth of the exchange-based contracts is the
  limited number of contracts available, one expert noted. Dealers, he
  said, are unable to secure a suitable hedge by laying off one
  contract against another.

  Although the various exchanges have had a good opportunity to
  establish a widely used set of new risk financing products, that has
  not been achieved, said Morton Lane, senior managing director,
  capital markets division at Gerling Global Financial Products in
  New York.

  The main problem with the existing exchanges is that they do not
  offer a sufficiently diverse array of products, he said. The only way
  to control the risks in the catastrophe options is to have a diversified
  portfolio of other contracts, and none of the exchanges currently
  offers a sufficiently broad range of options to provide for that
  hedge, he said.

  Florida windstorm options, for example, cannot be bought and then
  hedged in the same way that International Business Machines Corp.
  stock options contracts can be hedged with IBM stock, Mr. Lane
  explained.

  The exchanges might be more attractive to investors if, in addition to
  natural catastrophe options, they included options on other risks, he
  said. Those might include, for example, satellite, aviation and crop
  indexes, Mr. Lane said. "For the insurance buyer, such exchange
  instruments would not represent the perfect risk transfer vehicle, but
  as long as they are quantifiable and indexable, they may represent a
  good surrogate," he said.

  The exchanges could also be used to create a derivatives market for
  over-the-counter securitized deals, if there are regular issuers of
  catastrophe bonds, Mr. Lane said.

  The soft insurance market has also hindered the growth of
  exchange-based insurance products, said Sean F. Mooney, senior
  vp and chief economist at Guy Carpenter & Co., the reinsurance
  brokerage unit of Marsh Inc. in New York.

  "The traditional market has been so competitive that people are not
  looking for other ways of doing business," he said.

  At least in concept, the exchange-based deals are generally similar
  to the mortgage-backed securities that have been a huge success
  since they were introduced in the 1970s. "There is a belief that
  alternative means of transferring risks will grow, but it is difficult to
  predict when," Mr. Mooney said.

  Currently, the trading that is taking place typically involves
  established insurers and reinsurers, so the exchanges have not
  brought substantial new capacity to the marketplace, he said.

  Guy Carpenter provided the index for the Bermuda Commodities
  Exchange reinsurance products. The BCE did not take off,
  however, and was suspended last year after two years of little
  activity.

  The oldest of the insurance-related, exchange-based derivative
  products are the catastrophe options traded on the Chicago Board
  of Trade, which began trading the options in 1996.

  Initially, there was substantial interest in the options, but the soft
  traditional market has hampered use of the contracts to hedge
  catastrophe exposures, said Carlton Purty, an independent broker
  at the CBOT who trades in options.

  No catastrophe option trades have been completed at the CBOT
  so far this year, he said. Last year, there was increased interest in
  the contracts because of Hurricane Floyd, but few contracts were
  traded, Mr. Purty said.

  "I think a major, major catastrophe will have to happen before they
  really take off," he said.

  The contracts offer real protection, and options dealers are keen to
  trade in a new niche, but the conventional insurance and reinsurance
  markets are so soft that few companies are turning to alternative
  coverage options, Mr. Purty said.

  The Catastrophe Risk Exchange, located in Princeton, N.J., has
  radically changed its structure since it was originally announced in
  mid-1996, and it is well positioned to expand, said Frank Sweeney,
  chief operating officer.

  CATEX initially planned to be a computer-based facility for
  reinsurers that would enable them to exchange catastrophe risks
  and to build balanced portfolios.

  But by the time the exchange was operational in November 1996, it
  was clear that most reinsurers and insurers interested in CATEX
  wanted only to buy and sell conventional reinsurance, Mr. Sweeney
  said.

  Although there was some interest in risk swapping, only a handful of
  risks were posted on the system, and none was traded, Mr.
  Sweeney said.

  Consequently, CATEX has become chiefly a "cash for cover"
  exchange, he said, noting that the risks reinsured on the exchange
  include property catastrophe coverage, aviation and liability
  coverages. CATEX also trades industry loss warranties, where
  coverage is triggered by an actual loss combined with an industry
  loss over an agreed threshold.

  Other adjustments to the exchange included making it accessible
  through the Internet in November 1998. And late last year, CATEX
  offered users the ability to set up smaller networks, allowing them
  form groups whose members do business only with one another.

  Since its inception, CATEX has completed about 450 trades,
  totaling $400 million in premium and more than $3 billion in limits,
  he said. CATEX's roughly 160 subscribers include reinsurers,
  insurers and corporate entities that purchase coverage through their
  captives, Mr. Sweeney said.

  "We obviously have a long way to go, but we are pretty satisfied
  with what we have achieved so far," Mr. Sweeney said.

  The exchange sees increased activity after major losses, as cedents
  seek to buy replacement coverage to offset depletions in their
  existing cover, he said. For example, Mr. Sweeney said, there was
  a flurry of activity after the European windstorms in December last
  year.

  Last September, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange entered the field
  of insurance-related derivatives when it began offering weather
  derivatives .

  Thus far, 420 futures contracts have been traded, said Larry
  Grannan, senior director in product marketing at the CME.

  Such contracts are designed to allow businesses to hedge against
  weather-related losses. For example, a utility may sell less power in
  a mild winter, and it would be able to use the futures to hedge a
  resultant fall in revenues.

  The exchange first offered heat-based indexes for Atlanta, Chicago,
  Cincinnati and New York. In January, it added Philadelphia, Dallas,
  Des Moines, Las Vegas, Tucson and Portland, and it began offering
  contracts based on cold weather.

  Currently, most of the trades are between securities dealers
  themselves, but, eventually, the contracts will likely be used more
  extensively by utilities and insurers, Mr. Grannan said.

  In addition, the futures contracts could be used as hedges for
  over-the-counter securitized deals, he said.




Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
This 2000 *Business Insurance* report critiques slow adoption of exchange-based insurance derivatives (e.g., catastrophe options, weather futures) due to limited product diversity, abundant traditional insurance capacity, and lack of major disasters. Experts suggest expansion into broader risks (e.g., aviation, crops) and securitized deals to boost demand.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Strategic Insights on Expanding Insurance Derivatives Portfolio

**Dear Vince,**

I came across a *Business Insurance* report from 2000 that offers some interesting perspectives on the adoption of exchange-based insurance derivatives—like catastrophe options and weather futures. The report highlights two key challenges: limited product diversity and an oversupply of traditional insurance capacity, which has slowed market growth, especially given the lack of major disasters in recent years.

The experts cited in the piece suggest that broadening our focus to new risk categories—such as aviation or agricultural exposures—could help drive demand. Additionally, they emphasize the potential of securitized deals as a way to further diversify and attract participants.

Given our strategic goals, I thought it might be worth revisiting these insights to explore how we could adapt or expand our derivatives offerings. Would you be open to a quick discussion on how we might leverage these ideas to enhance our market position?

Looking forward to your thoughts.

**Best regards,**
Vince Kaminski
[Your Position]
Enron Corporation

---
*Note: Since the "From" and "To" addresses are identical, I assumed this was a draft or internal note. If this is meant for an external recipient, adjust the tone or details as needed.*
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Updated Presentation Version – Deadline Confirmation

Hi Dawn,

I’ve coordinated with David Sobotka from Koch to align our presentations and avoid overlap. As discussed, I’ll keep the core sections on valuation paradigms intact but will add new material on accounting treatment of weather derivatives and additional case examples. David will focus on market evolution and standard structures, while we’ll both highlight specific deals executed by our firms.

I’ll send you the revised version next week. Could you please confirm the deadline for your reference? Let me know if there’s anything else you’d like me to include or adjust.

Thanks,
Vince

I hope this email finds you well! I came across a fantastic educational resource called **"Math Mistakes"** that I think could be incredibly useful for both teachers and students. It appears to be a platform where math errors can be analyzed to improve understanding—perfect for reinforcing learning through targeted feedback.

You might find it helpful for:
- **Teachers:** Identifying common misconceptions and tailoring instruction.
- **Students:** Reviewing mistakes in a structured way to build confidence.

Here’s the link to explore it further: **[Insert Math Mistakes Link Here]**

Let me know if you’d like to discuss how it could be integrated into your curriculum or if you’d prefer a demo. Happy to help!

Best regards,
**Vince Kaminski**
vince.kaminski@enron.co

Vince

subject: Prof. Carmon
original_content:
Yannis,

I have looked at the outline of the proposed course and
find that practically all the topics of the program are the
staple of what we do every day. I don't think Research  should spend 
money for this class.

If we want to establish a relationship, we can easily do it
by asking him to work on a research project.

Vince
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Vince emails Yannis, questioning the need for a paid course since its topics align with daily work. He suggests fostering collaboration via a research project instead, implying Research shouldn’t fund the class. Concise, informal tone.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Thoughts on the Paid Course & Alternative Collaboration

**Hi Yannis,**

I hope you're doing well. I came across the details for the upcoming paid course and wanted to share a thought—given that many of its topics directly align with our day-to-day work, I’m wondering if there’s a way we could explore these ideas collaboratively through a research project instead. It feels like the Research team’s budget might be better spent elsewhere, and a joint initiative could bring more value to both teams.

Let me know if you’d like to brainstorm how we could make this happen. Happy to dive in!

**Best,**
Vince

---
*Notes:*
- **Tone:** Professional yet approachable, with a hint of informality to match the context.
- **Structure:** Clear subject line, concise body, and open-ended closing to encourage discussion.
- **Key points:** Challenges the course’s necessity, proposes collaboration, and subtly questions funding allocation.
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Thoughts on the Course Proposal

Yannis,

I’ve reviewed the course outline and noticed that most of the topics align closely with what we handle on a daily basis. Doesn’t seem like Research should be funding this—it feels more like a natural extension of our work.

If we’re looking to build something together, I’d rather propose a research project instead. That way, we’re both contributing and getting value out of it.

Vince

subject: Re: zakup ksiazki "Inzynieria finansowa" w WN
original_content:
Pani Grazyno,

Dziekuje bardzo za wiadomosc. Autor ksiazki przeslal mi egzemplarz.
Na pewno skorzystam z okazji, by kupic inne ksiazki Pani wydawnictwa.
Any web-site I can access?

W. Kaminski






"Wydawnictwa Naukowo-Techniczne" <marketing@wnt.com.pl> on 03/01/2001 
09:57:19 AM
To: <vkamins@enron.com>
cc:  
Subject: zakup ksiazki "Inzynieria finansowa" w WNT



Uprzejmie informuje, ze do dnia dzisiejszego  nie wplynely pieniadze na 
zamowiona ksiazke, wobec czego uwazam to za rezygnacje  z zakupu. 
Serdecznie pozdrawiam.
Grazyna Piesniewska
extracted_context:
**Summary (48 words):**
Grazyna Piesniewska (WNT) cancels a book order (*"Inżynieria finansowa"*) due to unpaid funds. W. Kaminski replies, thanking her for the notice, mentions receiving a free copy, and asks about WNT’s website. Tone: polite, transactional. **Addressed to:** WNT (via email) + Grazyna Piesniewska.
recreated_email_context_only:
**Subject:** Follow-Up on *"Inżynieria Finansowa"* Order Cancellation

**Dear Grazyna Piesniewska and WNT Team,**

Thank you for your prompt notice regarding the cancellation of the order for *"Inżynieria finansowa."* We appreciate the transparency and will process the refund accordingly.

As a courtesy, we’ve included a complimentary copy of the book for your reference. Additionally, I’d be happy to share any updates or promotional materials if helpful—please let us know.

Could you also share the URL to WNT’s website for our records? We’d be delighted to feature your work in our future communications.

Looking forward to your response.

Best regards,
**Vince Kaminski**
*Enron Publishing*
vince.kaminski@enron.co

---
**Notes:**
- **Tone:** Polite, transactional, and slightly collaborative (aligns with "free copy" + website inquiry).
- **Structure:** Acknowledges cancellation, offers value (book), and requests minimal follow-up (website link).
- **Professionalism:** Clear subject line, concise body, and warm closing. Adjust tone if WNT’s past correspondence is more formal/casual.
recreated_email_rag:
**Subject:** Dziękujemy za informację o rezygnacji z zamówienia

**Pani Grazyno,**

Dziękuję bardzo za powiadomienie o rezygnacji z zamówienia książki *„Inżynieria finansowa”*. Autor przesłał mi bezpłatny egzemplarz, który oczywiście wykorzystam.

Czy mogę zapytać, czy na stronie Wydawnictwa Naukowo-Technicznego jest dostępny jakiś portal internetowy, gdzie mogę zapoznać się z ofertą książek?

Z poważaniem,
**W. Kaminski**
